text: Have a read <https://www.betfair.com/aboutUs/Betfair.Charges/#Premium>

attachments.title: Betfair
attachments.text: Sign up for a £30 FREE bet with Betfair. Cash Out your In-Play bets, place a Multiple and get the best value. We also offer Games, Poker, Bingo and Casino. Bet & Win now.

elements.text: Have a read

text:
```9.4.4 While those conditions accurately describe our most successful customers, they might also apply to new customers who have only bet in a few markets, or those whose accounts are in profit because of a significant big win. To ensure that those accounts are not inadvertently charged, we've added two further conditions: any single win that constitutes more than 50% of lifetime gross profits will be excluded from the calculation, and customers will only be considered for the Premium Charge after they have bet in more than 250 markets.

9.4.5 Each customer will also have a £1,000 allowance against the Premium Charge. This means that every customer considered for the Premium Charge will be exempted from the first £1,000 of the charge incurred.```

elements.text:
9.4.4 While those conditions accurately describe our most successful customers, they might also apply to new customers who have only bet in a few markets, or those whose accounts are in profit because of a significant big win. To ensure that those accounts are not inadvertently charged, we've added two further conditions: any single win that constitutes more than 50% of lifetime gross profits will be excluded from the calculation, and customers will only be considered for the Premium Charge after they have bet in more than 250 markets.

9.4.5 Each customer will also have a £1,000 allowance against the Premium Charge. This means that every customer considered for the Premium Charge will be exempted from the first £1,000 of the charge incurred.

text: I think they recognise it has flaws and have some regrets over its introduction but they need(ed) some way of recovering their cost of acquisition. text: You need liquidity to be a successful exchange. Liquidity needs customers. Customers need to be bought (cost of acquisition). If you buy fish and the sharks eat them all then you are back to having no liquidity. Hence, premium charge

text: I am not sure about <@U016535QCJ2>’s firm / client but gathering from talking to various people in the sport betting prop trading businesses, the top operations make £30-£150M a year for the first few firm sized players; power law distribution so tapers off fast. These are full blown businesses with 100+ employees.

elements.text: I am not sure about

’s firm / client but gathering from talking to various people in the sport betting prop trading businesses, the top operations make £30-£150M a year for the first few firm sized players; power law distribution so tapers off fast. These are full blown businesses with 100+ employees.

elements.text: Is there any career progression in those sorts of outfits?

text: Not really. I was different to pretty much everyone who currently works for these organisations, and there are probably no jobs left for me for these sized clients anymore. I brought in existing software (an application framework, and generic code I already had), to each of these clients, so I was employed more as someone who developed and deployed self-contained systems rather than as a developer

elements.text: Not really. I was different to pretty much everyone who currently works for these organisations, and there are probably no jobs left for me for these sized clients anymore. I brought in existing software (an application framework, and generic code I already had), to each of these clients, so I was employed more as someone who developed and deployed self-contained systems rather than as a developer

text: Swings and roundabouts. Great benefits to the clients while I was there. No real benefit when I left because they lost most of the knowledge of the systems. I worked with developers at both clients, but nobody really seemed interested in how I did what I did. Everyone there sees development as a "sausage factory", and just thinks that anyone is replaceable. They possibly are, but often at great cost

text: Last lesson from Pure Maths: take time to understand the problem, so that you can break the bigger problem into a number of smaller problems. The better you understand the subject, the smaller those individual problems are, and the easier they are to "solve"

elements.text: Last lesson from Pure Maths: take time to understand the problem, so that you can break the bigger problem into a number of smaller problems. The better you understand the subject, the smaller those individual problems are, and the easier they are to "solve"

text: And then once you "solve" them, keep looking for more "elegant" solutions. By elegant I mean simpler and less moving parts. My model that I have refined over the past few months uses a "minimal" set of data and only a few arbitrary threshold values. It's now much simpler than it was a month ago

elements.text: And then once you "solve" them, keep looking for more "elegant" solutions. By elegant I mean simpler and less moving parts. My model that I have refined over the past few months uses a "minimal" set of data and only a few arbitrary threshold values. It's now much simpler than it was a month ago

text: It's minimal in breadth (fields) but large in depth (number of records)

elements.text: It's minimal in breadth (fields) but large in depth (number of records)
